utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: Nike is going all in on the new ad campaign featuring controversial quarterback Colin Kaepernick. The first commercial airs during the NFL season opener. Here's the preview.

utterances.speaker: COLIN KAEPERNICK, NFL QUARTERBACK
utterances.sentences: People say your dreams are crazy. If they laugh at what you think you can do. Good. Stay that way. Believe in something, even if it means sacrificing everything. So don't ask if your dreams are crazy. Ask if they're crazy enough.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: So, guys, I mean, I'm watching that. And, you know, obviously, this is a very controversial topic. I've been social media hated on because I have discussed it a little bit myself. But, you know, my take is on this, Colin Kaepernick, you know, he was an athlete. I don't know if he's Serena Williams level, because she's also in this commercial. My biggest concern is the word "sacrifice." And what is it that he actually sacrificed? And although I'm not a huge sports fanatic, he wasn't in the prime of his career during all this. So it's not like he gave up something big. But now he's definitely a face, and he definitely has some new money coming in because of all this controversy. So what is your take on it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Here's what bugs me about the story. I am so against talking about this story, because that has been the strategy behind this all along. It's not about the action but the reaction. The ripple effect created by this decision gets free media. We play the ad that Nike did not have to pay for. What bugs me is that we're all in on this. Because if we really were disgusted by Nike, we wouldn't give the oxygen to Nike. We wouldn't play the ad. But we know that this makes good TV; it's good outrage TV. The people that are for Colin love the response they're getting. And I just want to quote Scott Adams. Just One More Thing, and I'll shut up. The real harm -- harmful part of these ads is encouraging kids to take part in harmful activity that risks permanent injury. Skateboarding -- to prove that you can skateboard on a rail offers no transferrable skills later in life, other than perhaps you might have a head injury, and that's not transferrable. So that -- believing that that's an achievement and don't quit, that's the absurdity.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: My son is currently on crutches right now because he had ankle surgery from a skateboarding injury. So --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go. I am, like, an expert.

utterances.sentences: He's a doctor.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm an expert.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I agree with you, in that part of it is just that, you know, any billion-dollar brand, Nike employs some of the world's best marketers, and they knew exactly what they were doing here. This isn't altruistic in any sort. This is a marketing ploy. And it's going to work. What do you think, Dana?

So if you have someone like ourselves who's like, "What did he sacrifice? Because he didn't really have the -- what it took to be on a great team anymore. And now he made a decision. There were consequences for that decision. I think there's a lesson in that, right? There's consequences for that decision. The consequence for him is that he ends up being able to be extremely famous.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Millions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And got a lot of money for this. But he's also -- I don't doubt that he believes in what he's saying. We believe in what we're saying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He hates cops.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And I just don't see how to bring them together. I am at a loss for that, and I'm sad about it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's the socks!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, no, I'm talking about the socks that he wore. That will always be in my craw. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sorry, you're here, Jesse!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

But with that said, the myth of Colin Kaepernick. That's what this was about. He was created by the media. He was one and eleven the last year. Remember, he was benched. OK? They they brought him back in. He went one and eleven. He was on a year-to-year contract which was performance based, because his agent and the Niners knew he wasn't that good. Defenses figured him out; he was a running quarterback. Couldn't read defenses. Had a semi-accurate arm. And he was on the down slope of his career. utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I must say that the guy who made this, Jesse, is not Colin Kaepernick who started this, and it got really meager attention until Donald Trump got in and then started calling NFL players SOBs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Scary.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: Everyone gets nervous at this point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You don't sound like you believe what the authorities are saying?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: I -- to be honest, I don't know yet. I don't have enough information. I would like to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Vanilla Ice was on the flight.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: They did say that -- that was the best part.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We hope Vanilla Ice and everybody else on the flight are OK. I have two questions; it's a two-parter. What is the best cure for a hangover? And what are your feelings about Juuls?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: Oh, the vaping Juuls?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The vaping, yes.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: I get, like, I love jewels. Best cure for a hangover? I don't know. Drink less.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No! That's not what I was looking for.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Good answer. Good answer.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: I mean, I'm going to give you the same thing everyone does. Lots of water. Take it easy. Maybe a Tylenol. And some people say, you know, you have a drink in the morning. I'm not going to say that I do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hair of the dog. I like that.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: But I will say that people say that that works.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You have a good bedside manner.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: Vaping, very concerned about vaping. I have three kids myself. One of them just going off to college. And I know it's rampant out there. It's similar to cigarettes. We don't have the data on it. We don't know long-term consequences.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Without the tar. Without the tar.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: We do absolutely know that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I want a second opinion.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: We absolutely know that there is can be -- cause severe lung damage with JUULs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK, Greg. Did you hear that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I want to see the research.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: Especially those that have flavors. There is research.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I've not seen it. I'm questioning -- it doesn't have the tar in it. It's obviously better than smoking. Obviously.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg, you have some questions for her?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK, yes, it's kind of a maybe a two-parter. OK, when I'm in a car and the car's going downhill, I always get this weird feeling in my stomach. In my stomach. And it's the same feeling I get, like, when I'm on a roller coaster. It's also the same feeling when people talk about their health problems. I get this weird feeling. It's almost like -- do you ever stick your finger in your bellybutton and you get that weird feeling? What is that weird feeling? What is that? Is that what you call squeamishness or is it, like, some nervous system?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The jollies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Is it a ghost?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: OK, well, that's not actually covered in medical school. But I'm going to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But you know what I'm talking about?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: So of course it is. It's a mix: it's mental and physical. So physically what's happening, when you roller coaster, when you go down that, you're actually -- gravity. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: So the gas and the contents in your intestines and your stomach move.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow!

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: So you're feeling it. Also, your brain has fear, anxiety, and that has direct impulses.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He has a lot of those.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: No fear, Jesse. And it gets them to move a little bit more. So you're feeling a lot of different things. The bellybutton thing? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's really weird. I do it sometimes, and then it freaks me out, and I ask myself why I'm doing it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Medical mystery.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Her advice is to stop doing that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: My -- I have 2 questions. One is, because you do breast cancer diagnoses and treatment, there is confusion out there about whether women should get mammograms yearly. What's your opinion?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: You know, we should talk about this for an entire hour, because that would save a lot of lives. A lot of confusion around that, and the main thing is, I recommend for average risk women, you know, there's 1 in 8 women will get breast cancer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: Everyone knows a woman who's gotten it. For average risk women, a mammogram every year starting at age 40 until you don't think that you're necessarily going to live for 5 to 10 years after that. Confusion, because people like to talk about mortality. And although -- although sometimes you may diagnose breast cancer early, you treat it. That gives you 10 to 20 years. But you still may die from your breast cancer. So when you're looking at numbers, they say, "Well, they're still dying." Well, let me tell you, when I tell a 38-year-old woman that she has breast cancer and she has two toddlers at home, those 10 to 20 years are a big deal to her. So get your mammograms. Get them every year.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg wants to know what happens when you die?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was going to ask why I can't tickle myself. But I would go with I'd like to know what happens when we die. And then tell me why I can't tickle myself.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: What do you mean when you die? Spiritually, physically?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh! I want to know what you think.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: I know what you think.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know -- I want to know what you believe consciousness is. Is it some kind of --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Ten seconds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This is for the podcast, Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, one for he podcast.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? But I think he's got a point, because in the Trump era, it's a good question. What happens if you die?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Moral death?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Leave it to Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Help us, death.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I just think -- I'm just interested in what this is. Consciousness. Is this some kind of steam arising from body functions? Or is it a combination of --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. All right. Scott Adams, we've got to go. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Time for "One More Thing." Let's go to Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, Gregory, Burt Reynolds died this morning at the age of 82. Reynolds was Hollywood's top-grossing star from 1978 to 1982, the longest period any actor dominated Hollywood since Bing Crosby in the 1940s. Reynolds was also famous, of course, for appearing as a "Cosmopolitan" centerfold, and he was one of the few men to ever appear on the cover of "Playboy." Reynolds is best known for his leading role in the movie "Smokey and the Bandit," which grossed more than "Star Wars" did in 1977. Can you believe that? He won an Oscar nomination for his role in "Boogie Nights." Reynolds was also famous for his relationships with people like Chris Evert, Loni Anderson and the woman he called the love of his life, Sally Fields. What a life he had. Burt Reynolds, rest in peace.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Best day he ever did, though, "Deliverance," but nobody ever says that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: "Smokey."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Better than "Smokey." All right, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. With the NFL starting tonight, most people are excited about the games, but a lot of people here, you know we love the food. Stadiums are adding some more snacks that we hate to love, because they're so good. But I don't know if they're good for you. But the doctor here says we can eat them, because she likes them. Some of these new game day treats include fried ravioli, cheese melts, fried peanut butter and jelly sandwiches on a stick. And if Jesse if going to eat some, he's got to wear this hat that we got for him. This is an NFL hat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I can't eat it until I put this on?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. So if you could -- there you go. Actually, maybe that's pretty good. OK, so fried ravioli for you and a cheese melt. Have fun at the games everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's going to live forever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, so gross.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There goes your career.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I like this better than the haircut, I'll tell you that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, that's it. Don't you dare.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow, your hair didn't even move.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I've got to do this quick.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Auctioneer News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Auctioneer News." We don't get a lot of auctioneer news, but yesterday in the midst of a hearing with Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, there was some nut-bag protester yelling and screaming. And Billy Long, which -- is he is a congressman?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: From Missouri?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. He's also an auctioneer, and he had the perfect way of silencing the hecklers.

utterances.speaker: REP. BILLY LONG (R), MISSOURI
utterances.sentences: How many, 12 and a half, 15. Seven and a half, $20, seven and a half, $30. Count thirty dollar down, half. Thirty- five, seven and a half, 40. Cut three and a quarter now. Three and a half. Four hundred. Hey, but a four. Four and a quarter. I yield back.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Every hearing should have one auctioneer, because nobody remembers the protester.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He was great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was great. All right. So here's some special fans from Long Island, Fort Salonga, Long Island, actually. From left to right, we have Braden, Noah in the middle and J.T. on the right. I let them getting away with not popping the collar. It's fine. They're a little young for that. You know, they don't want to attract too much attention. But these kids are good kids, patriots and "Watters' World" fans. So they have great taste. Thanks boys.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That was a real --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That was a great "One More Thing."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Just, like, a picture. You have really mailed it in today, I have to say. Dr. Saphier.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: I have a very special graduation to talk about. Little Cullen, who was born less than a pound at 22 weeks --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, God.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: -- which many people deemed nonviable. He is now graduating, leaving the NICU, going home at 6 pounds. His parents were initially told he only had a 2 percent chance of living, and here he is. He is healthy. He has -- requires a little bit oxygen, but he is amazing. He is that child who was not supposed to live. But modern medicine and his parents' determination and perseverance has gotten him this far. And there he is. He is wearing a cap and gown from Build a Bear.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And he'll catch up, right?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: Catch up in terms of size?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: We'll see. Time will tell. I mean, sometimes when you're born really early, you tend to be a little --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He might be taller than you, Dana.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: You never know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What happens to appendixes when you take them out? Do they go somewhere?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.sentences: I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Is there a jar?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can you get back to us on that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know, I mean fried livers are good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Terrible. All right. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. That's Bret Baier, to my right. utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello. I'm Spartacus with Dr. Nichole Saphier, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and she uses a step ladder to get on a step ladder, Dana Perino -- "The Five." All right, about that anonymous op-ed by a so-called "senior official" in the New York Times trashing the president for his style and coarseness. Yep, they went after Trump for being Trump. I know, shocking. The Times said this story was published at the request of the author, which is the way the Times used to sell classified ads. Next time I want to do 1,200 words of the destructiveness of the mainstream media. I'll just call ahead and make a reservation. I, joke. That only works if you're in the resistance where you can claim it's about restoring civility, but it's really about unseating Trump.

utterances.speaker: But within all this phoniness, only one sentence really mattered
utterances.utterance: When Captain Anonymous said the country is already safer and more prosperous. Wait a minute, so the country is safer and more prosperous under Trump, but not nicer to dolphins or more likely to recycle? Let's impeach this guy. Yep, just two silly variables, security and prosperity, which happen to be the best variables ever. Seriously then, what's left to critique? His style. Trump is a big meanie. He's worse than Darth. Please, tell it to H.R. I'll take the deeds, you cry about the words. Because we've already get it, Trump is an intense boss who asks tons of questions and makes you feel bad because he's not like your old boss, the one that almost sank the company. Also, Trump never buys doughnuts and leaves his dirty coffee mug in the sink.

utterances.speaker: So if you believe that this Times piece hurt Trump, you might be dumb enough to read the Times. It doesn't hurt him a bit. The scoop
utterances.utterance: Trump's not nice. That's not journalism. That's clickbait. So well done, New York Times, you may be the paper of record but it's a broken one.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: You forgot that he microwaves cauliflower.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. He puts.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes. And eats fish in the greenroom.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I defend that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's absolutely disgusting. I have to go to Dr. Saphier first because you sound like a character from a Marvel comic.

utterances.speaker: NICOLE SAPHIER, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I am.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dr. Saphier, doesn't this op-ed validate what people believe the deep state is, and that Trump will appear to be the victim to many of his supporters?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: But I'll be honest, I can't put much merit in a self- congratulatory letter that is, you know, behind the cloak of anonymity because you can say anything you want if you're not putting your name behind it. And a part of this inside the letter, they were essentially saying, you know, don't worry America. Adults are in the White House. You know what they're doing? They're causing more mass hysteria. What they could have done if they're really wanting to make people feel better about what's going on is to actually discuss the accomplishments that the administration has achieved in the last couple of years. That would let America feel a little bit better about these adults being in said White House. This is just another provocative thing. And if you aren't going to put your name on it, you can't refute it. It's -- I find it to be very pathetic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse, why should this person remain anonymous? If he comes out he's going to be a mythical folk hero to like half -- well, all the media and the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he's going to land a gig at MSNBC.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He might already have it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Or CNN. We were joking in the greenroom, you know, who do you think it is? Who do you think it is? I don't think it's that funny. I think this is very, very serious. And it's probably the biggest scandal in my opinion within the Trump administration so far. All of the other scandals have been about personnel and bickering and something crazy Trump said off the record. This is a conspirator and he's got a cabal of other conspirators inside the White House getting paid by the taxpayer. He's unelected. He's got buddies. And they're preventing the president for executing his vision for making America great again. It's incredibly dangerous. There's no way this guy is ever going to be identified because I don't think Sessions is capable of smoking this person out. We know what his motivation is, it's self-center. We had a mole here at Fox News and he was smoked out in about -- less than 48 hours. And his motivation was a cry for help and a cry for attention. And this is exactly what this is. And it reminds me of Peter Strzok. Remember Peter Strzok?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He was an ego maniac who thought it was his duty, even though he wasn't elected, to protect the country from Donald Trump. And he took really bad actions to do that behind-the-scenes. This is the exact same thing. And I'm really worried about it. I really am.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Do you think there's merit, there's truth to this? Do you think it's actually occurring or are they just saying this is a fear factor?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: My theory is it's a class of management style. They're not used to working for a boss. They're used to working for a politician. That's my theory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you know what? Because businessmen -- when businessmen do things they do it right away and they do it now, and it's very impulsive, and it's what the CEO wants. Politicians, usually -- right -- the markets move fast, you've got to move quickly. Politicians they consult with allies, with their advisors, with everybody around them. And it takes forever to get anything done. And then Trump comes in here and says lets rip up the trade deal with South Korea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or ask a lot of questions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And it terrifies people because a lot of these people are Wall Street guys, and they don't want to ruin the markets. They don't want to affect the markets. And a lot of things are done in order for Wall Street not to take hits. But I think -- look at Wall Street right now, on a pretty good run.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. And speaking of a good run, Juan. I feel like this is like a game of Clue. Like, who could this be? Could it be Ms. Scarlet or Ms. Peacock -- Mrs. Peacock? I never played Clue.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, I know that Dana is my load star in this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think that would indicate Mike Pence is a suspect, although he said he's not the guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Could be his speechwriter.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Could be. I don't think so. No, because I think the Times understands once you say it's a senior administration official, given the possibility this person is out, you better have a senior administration official and not somebody on the back bench. But I'm taken by your monologue because, to me, again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . you seem to want to normalize, minimize, never, ever pay attention to Trump. And I must say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . here's a point -- here's a point of agreement I have with you guys. I think whoever wrote it really needs to stand up because, to my mind, what this is, is a Republican in the administration kind of saying, hey, you know what, we understand, this guy maybe is not fit to be president and we're here, we're watching him, we're cautious about everything. Things are not going well, by the way, despite what you hear from Greg. I mean, the fact is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Greatest economy in years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, let me just say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Militarily, unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: America is a great country and keeps going despite his antics. But I must say, his numbers, according to the American people, the lowest for any president ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't have to like somebody to admit they're doing a great job. Trust me, I know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The key thing here to me is that you have other publications, Axios saying people have -- are saying the same thing. Oh, I could have written that inside the White House, administration officials telling Axios. You have the book from Bob Woodward. You have the Michael Wolff book. You have the -- they're all the same story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This guy is not making rational decisions and he's scaring the people in the White House.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. So, Dana, to his point, I would argue and you can -- OK, none of these complaints are new. We know what Trump is about. He's mercurial. He's brash. He asks a lot of questions, and a lot of questions are innocently naive because he's not a politician. And then, I think, that this article is turning into manage -- he's being managed by his staff as evidence that he's dangerous. I don't see that, but.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No. Well, I said yesterday, I think that this person should definitely resign. There're a lot of benefits that you get from being a senior administration official. I mean, but that could also include, like, the deputy undersecretary of the such and such division at the department of transportation. I mean -- I don't think that --they don't have a cabinet member or something like that saying this because that would be ridiculous. I don't think that anybody in his cabinet would be so cowardly to do this and hide behind anonymity. And I think, also -- would be impossible to keep it a secret. Here's the thing though about this person. They think they're doing such a good job of keeping the country safe from him. But what this really does is very aggravating to a president. And what they're saying is that they're responsible -- to keeping the presidency from devolving into something that none of us want.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But the President of the United States, no matter who he or she is has so much on their plate. So much responsibility. The number one thing is to protect the American people from all threats. That is the most important job. So, if you're really actually worried about his state of mind, why aggravate him further by issuing an op-ed that does nothing but just provide you with some sort of cover so that when you go out to seek some sort of private sector position, you can say I was the one behind that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I pick up on this in respond to you, Dana? To my mind, this person said that Trump is detrimental to the United States.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Then resign.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's right. But the other thing that they say that caught my attention was what about the 25th amendment?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Can I quote Liz Warren?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. So, this is to Juan's point, she said if senior administration officials think the President of the United States is not able to do his job, then they should invoke the 25th amendment. I think she is right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what I was about to say to Dana, that, in fact, if you want to say, this guy say or woman say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But they should say it then.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . they don't want to spark a constitutional crisis. Otherwise, they would invoke the 25th, because what they're saying is this guy is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think they believe it.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Invoke then impeachment. So, if we're not going.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, but my point.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Again, this is just causing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. But my point is that this person in writing this is making the case. This person, the president, is a danger to us all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What about the idea that he thinks -- so what if Russia is interfering in our elections. Not a big deal according to him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We've just killed a bunch of Russians.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What about the idea that, oh, I'm going to attack all of the law enforcement in our country because they should be protecting me, not the American people?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Cops love him. Cops love him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, please. FBI, CIA, they don't love him. What about the corruption in this administration? What about the racism in this -- dividing us all.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would go to my point and talk to you about danger because this is not a dangerous situation. ISIS has been destroyed. There's more peace prospects.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: ISIS destroyed?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, the stock market is doing great because of Trump's vision. The tax cuts were effective.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, thank you, Obama.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . because of Trump's vision.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Obama.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There're more jobs in this country because of Trump. You're not living in dangerous times. You're safe. We're all safe, and a lot more safer than under Barack Obama.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Take off those rose colored glasses, brother.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, put some on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. A political stunt blows up in Senator Cory Booker's face during the Kavanaugh hearings. The embarrassing video, that's next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Day three of the Brett Kavanaugh hearing, they're still underway. But what happened earlier is making headlines. Senator Cory Booker's bombshell revelation turns out to more of a bust. The junior senator claiming he was knowingly risking punishment for breaking senate rules by releasing confidential documents from Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. Turns out, the emails he made public have already been cleared for release before today's hearing. Here's how it played out.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CORY BOOKER, D-N.J.
utterances.utterance: I come from a long line, as all of us do as American, to understand what -- that kind of civil disobedience is and I understand the consequences. So I am, right now, before your process is finished, I'm going to release the email about racial profiling. And I understand that -- the penalty comes with potential ousting from the senate. And if Senator Cornyn believes that I violated senate rules, I openly invite and accept the consequences of my team releasing that email right now. I appreciate the comments of my colleagues. This is about the closest that I'll probably ever have in my life to I am Spartacus moments.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Republicans hitting back against Booker claiming it was all about his potential 2020 run. And it turns out that email that he release, Greg, it was about racial profiling, but Brett Kavanaugh was saying he was against racial profiling in the days after 9/11.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Spartacus indeed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, Spartacus.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I just like the way he talks. He talks like he's trying to eat a Subway sandwich. A really large sandwich. And so his mouth is really big when he's talking because -- he's annunciating while he's about to eat a giant sandwich and he can't stop. By the way, the Gorsuch -- this hearing is so predictable that you could run the Gorsuch hearing and no one would notice. No one would notice because it's -- America treats this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They went to high school together, Kavanaugh and Gorsuch.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, really, that's sweet. You know, it reminds me though of like -- I think America is treating this like a plant that you just check on periodically, like a ficus plant in a corner. They turn it, they see it, and they turn the other channel because it's so boring. We've been there. We know how it's going to end. Let's just vote.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what's boring? Last night.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I didn't watch that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Senator Hatch. Senator Hatch. So I went to a concert last night, thanks to you, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: ZZ Top.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I went to see ZZ Top. But, anyway, when I got back I saw a replay of Harris talking to Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And she said, hey, do you remember having a conversation with lawyers about the Mueller probe? And he's like, oh, gee -- me? Who, me? How could you ask that of me? I don't remember. Who are you talking about? Do you have anybody specific in mind at that law firm?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And that law firm said no.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Well, the point is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What is the point, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The point is because he -- this is an important point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He won't say whether or not.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So he said -- he refuses to say whether a sitting president can be indicted, right? He doesn't know if he can be subpoenaed. I mean, this is a guy who is supposed to be in the Supreme Court. Nominated by somebody who is under investigation and he won't do it. And then they say, hey, were you talking to the lawyers that the president's former lawyers firm and he say I don't remember. Come on, you remember. You just don't want to say.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I think we're watching different hearings because I watched the exact same thing. And these senators aren't that smart. I think journalists are smarter than these people. They're all briefed by their young staffs, and especially Blumenthal. He's trying to like nail this guy down on whether he spoke about Mueller. And our nominee that we're watching right here, ran circles around him. And it was embarrassing for Blumenthal. And Blumenthal should be embarrassed because the guy lied about going to Vietnam. And now he thinks he has the stomach to challenge the integrity of a Supreme Court nominee? I mean, this guy is not an intelligent person. He looked dumb. He looked unprepared. And he lied about going to war. I mean, what do you do? Could you imagine, Juan, you made up a story, not just a little white lie? I went and served and fought in a war overseas for many, many years, and he lied about that for years. And he's in the senate now and he's acting like he's all high-and-mighty.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Don't you always say to me, Trump won an election? I believe that Senator Blumenthal has been elected by.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Let's get Dr. Saphier in here.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: So, Senator Harris last night, you know, she asked (INAUDIBLE) she asked if he talked to a lawyer that was a part of this mega law firm with like over 350 attorneys. I wouldn't know. But that aside, I didn't like that she kept homing in on him asking him his opinions on different things. I'm not concerned with his opinions on controversial events. I'm more concerned with his ability to objectively uphold our federal law and without prejudices. Those are the questions that need to be asked. They need to stop trying to get him on, you know, tongue-tying, messing up his words, and that's what they're really doing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, what would you include?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: So, I -- in regards to Charlottesville?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, no, in regards to whether or not he can be an impartial judge?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: . just because the subject says racial profiling, doesn't mean he's for it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the email was cleared for release. So the whole thing was a stunt.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So why this morning the whole I am Spartacus.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: If they expelled him from the senate that probably would have helped him actually. But.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am Spartacus disgusting. Hey, you know what I want to point out? Nobody talked about the fact that Brett Kavanaugh using sharpies. Have you noticed that? He's the only nominee ever. He uses a sharpie just like me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So does Strzok, though. So, I don't know. That might be disqualifying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sharpies are the greatest instrument of communication since the Guttenberg press.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, it's saying something. It's quite an innovation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It really is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, I'm going to move on. The RNC dropped a new ad for trying extremist Democrats as unhinged. Get it? Next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The Republican National Committee turning up the heat ahead of the mid-terms. They released a blistering new ad highlighting left-wing anger and outrage. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Please, get up in the face of some congresspeople.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: You see anybody from that cabinet in a restaurant, in a department store, or a gasoline station, you get up and you (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I just don't even know why there aren't uprising all across the country.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. So, Jesse, I think the idea here is this will say to Republicans, oh, my gosh, Democrats have gone too far left. Too crazy. Too radical. You can't vote for them. Is that what you hear?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's watch it again.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You love that ad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's loop it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You love it, huh?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I do. I think it's a good ad because it shows the Democrats in their own skin and saying the things and doing the things that they accuse other people of. They say Trump is crazy, Trump is radical. The right is dangerous. The right is violent. Yet, they themselves are the ones encouraging violence.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait, wait.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . encouraging bad actions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think a lot of people listen to Maxine, no relation, and take those comments as something that -- when you say get in someone's face and you see him at a gas station, that's a little -- instigates a lot of people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So, Dana.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . and I don't think that's good. And it's a lot different than what you see coming out from -- about Donald Trump. All the anonymous sources of this is what someone heard someone say. There you have it in living color.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So, but, Dana, then the other side is that, in fact, the left may be thrilled with this ad and it might excite people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is what they want?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Say, yeah, we want somebody who's going to stand up and take it to Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't run it again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, right now, I think that -- because people are so interested in politics, unlike before, usually you'll only get people really solidified on their vote after Labor Day, but not so this case this year. For example, in Florida, apparently, 90 percent of voters, likely voters, have already decided who they're going to vote for. That leaves very few people for the taking. So, this ad is it to meant to get Republicans off to vote or would it motivate Democrats to get out to vote? I don't know. It's going to be fascinating to watch because, right now, like the governor's race in Florida, 50-50.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, Doc McStuffings.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, if you think about this ad and in this moment, do you believe, as Dana was saying, that it really changes anything? Because, previously, the Republicans were going to run on tax cuts or deregulation, none of that seem to be working so they're going to ads like -- and I expect they're going to go after the NFL players who kneel and after immigrants and gangs, what's going on?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: I think it's really for entertainment purposes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I think we're missing the big story here, that this is insulting to the band Crazy Town, who are known for one hit. I believe it was called "Butterfly."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I like that song. Such a cool movie video.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And it was -- and it was a great scene in "Donnie Darko," if people remember that movie. I would be -- I would warn about laughing about this stuff, because this is exactly what CNN did with Trump. They devoted tons of air time without devoting any serious consideration to the candidates, because they thought, "Hey, Trump is crazy. He's going to lose." He was the joke; he was the butt of the joke. But the butt of the joke kicked their butts. That's why I'm really -- I really say you've got to be very careful about just openly dismissing --

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: That's interesting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- progressive people on the side, because that's what CNN did with Trump. I mean, they got him elected.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And the left is highly energized.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Look at what happened in that primary election in Massachusetts this past weekend.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Two liberals. But the -- the younger one, the not older white guy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: More aggressive.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: More aggressive.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's my point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She's not violent in any way.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: By no means. I don't mean that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't buy that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There is energy on the left.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But Greg, you don't like the ad, huh?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: -- health care and corruption, and so that's what they want to focus on. And so when you have people energized like this that talk about getting rid of corruption, I do think that's going to get some people's attention.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Nike kicking off the NFL season with a controversial new Colin Kaepernick commercial. We're going to show it to you, delight you with it, next.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Nike is going all in on the new ad campaign featuring controversial quarterback Colin Kaepernick. The first commercial airs during the NFL season opener. Here's the preview.

utterances.speaker: COLIN KAEPERNICK, NFL QUARTERBACK
utterances.utterance: People say your dreams are crazy. If they laugh at what you think you can do. Good. Stay that way. Believe in something, even if it means sacrificing everything. So don't ask if your dreams are crazy. Ask if they're crazy enough.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: So, guys, I mean, I'm watching that. And, you know, obviously, this is a very controversial topic. I've been social media hated on because I have discussed it a little bit myself. But, you know, my take is on this, Colin Kaepernick, you know, he was an athlete. I don't know if he's Serena Williams level, because she's also in this commercial. My biggest concern is the word "sacrifice." And what is it that he actually sacrificed? And although I'm not a huge sports fanatic, he wasn't in the prime of his career during all this. So it's not like he gave up something big. But now he's definitely a face, and he definitely has some new money coming in because of all this controversy. So what is your take on it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Here's what bugs me about the story. I am so against talking about this story, because that has been the strategy behind this all along. It's not about the action but the reaction. The ripple effect created by this decision gets free media. We play the ad that Nike did not have to pay for. What bugs me is that we're all in on this. Because if we really were disgusted by Nike, we wouldn't give the oxygen to Nike. We wouldn't play the ad. But we know that this makes good TV; it's good outrage TV. The people that are for Colin love the response they're getting. And I just want to quote Scott Adams. Just One More Thing, and I'll shut up. The real harm -- harmful part of these ads is encouraging kids to take part in harmful activity that risks permanent injury. Skateboarding -- to prove that you can skateboard on a rail offers no transferrable skills later in life, other than perhaps you might have a head injury, and that's not transferrable. So that -- believing that that's an achievement and don't quit, that's the absurdity.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: My son is currently on crutches right now because he had ankle surgery from a skateboarding injury. So --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go. I am, like, an expert.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's a doctor.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm an expert.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Yes, I agree with you, in that part of it is just that, you know, any billion-dollar brand, Nike employs some of the world's best marketers, and they knew exactly what they were doing here. This isn't altruistic in any sort. This is a marketing ploy. And it's going to work. What do you think, Dana?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.utterance: Well, I've been trying to figure out a way. How do you look past this, like, from a paradigm shift or, like, three weeks from now? There are obviously people who are very excited about this ad. And they really believe that Colin Kaepernick has sacrificed something. So if you have someone like ourselves who's like, "What did he sacrifice? Because he didn't really have the -- what it took to be on a great team anymore. And now he made a decision. There were consequences for that decision. I think there's a lesson in that, right? There's consequences for that decision. The consequence for him is that he ends up being able to be extremely famous.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Millions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And got a lot of money for this. But he's also -- I don't doubt that he believes in what he's saying. We believe in what we're saying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He hates cops.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I just don't see how to bring them together. I am at a loss for that, and I'm sad about it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the socks!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Big and Rich, is that who did the socks?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, no, I'm talking about the socks that he wore. That will always be in my craw. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: That is absolutely going against police enforcement. That's a whole other thing. I mean, Jesse, what are your takes on this? Has Nike now stepped into the political debate?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they have, and the NFL is not happy about it. Nike stock took a big beating, and then it stabilized the next day. But they know how to make millions and billions of dollars. So, you know, if I knew how to do they, I'd probably be on vacation or working for Nike. So I'm not going to do what they're going to do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sorry, you're here, Jesse!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The probably have -- Listen, if I was worth what Nike was worth, I'm sorry. I wouldn't be on "The Five." I'd be at a beach with a pina colada. But with that said, the myth of Colin Kaepernick. That's what this was about. He was created by the media. He was one and eleven the last year. Remember, he was benched. OK? They they brought him back in. He went one and eleven. He was on a year-to-year contract which was performance based, because his agent and the Niners knew he wasn't that good. Defenses figured him out; he was a running quarterback. Couldn't read defenses. Had a semi-accurate arm. And he was on the down slope of his career. He started kneeling, because he knew he was getting cut and tried to reinvent himself. And the media came in, and they made this guy a hero, when he didn't deserve it, because the real heroes are the cops on his socks that he mocked.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Don't forget: he didn't start by kneeling. He started by sitting on the bench. He didn't even show that respect. It wasn't until someone pointed out that it's actually disrespectful to our --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He won't even go on a TV show that's going to ask him tough questions.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: My question for you is do you think this is Nike taking a chance on discrimination, or is this just a marketing ploy, and they're happy to reap financial benefits over the long term?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, of course they're happy to reap financial benefits. They also took a little bit of a hit. But as Jesse pointed out, they rebounded financially, and I think they're going to rebound even further, because they understand -- and he statistics show that people -- young people in specific but people who buy athletic gear, love this idea of taking a stand on a social issue and demonstrating --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's easy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- they're willing to take the punishment, that you're willing to make the sacrifice. You know, I disagree with you guys. I think Colin Kaepernick is better than most of the back-up quarterbacks in the NFL.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not any more.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I must say that the guy who made this, Jesse, is not Colin Kaepernick who started this, and it got really meager attention until Donald Trump got in and then started calling NFL players SOBs.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, we were talking about Kaepernick on FOX News for a year and a half before Trump got involved.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You go back and check about --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Check the tapes, Juan. Go to the tapes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You check and see how often. But here's the thing. I think that the police union really had a terrific response on this, because they said, "We're not calling for any boycott of Nike. But guess what? Police officers make sacrifices, too, every day."

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And I think that's a measured and thoughtful response, unlike some -- you know, some of the blowhards at 1600 Pennsylvania.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Well, we're just contributing to, like, to this entire thing by continuing to talk about it. So we're going to move on now. So stay with us, because up next, these guys are putting me in the hot seat for the first time on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She doesn't just play one for TV purpose. Turns out Dr. Saphier is actually a pretty big deal. She's the director of radiology fore breast imaging at one of the largest cancer hospitals in the area. And we've been peppering her with questions since before the show started, so we've cancelled our previously-planned segment to talk to her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I ask a question?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wait.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, do you want to go first?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I would.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, fine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So in the news yesterday a plane is stopped at LaGuardia. They take people off, and they stick them in containers, and they transfer -- and everybody thinks, "What happened? Are we in danger?" And we never find out. What do you know?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: I mean, it sounds like what they're saying right now is they think it has to do with flu and the common cold. I mean, that's the story they're giving us right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's not very sexy. I thought it was Ebola or something good.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: There's a lot of conspiracy theories: Ebola, something. All we know is that they had bunch of people who were sick on the airplane. It sounds like they were actually sick before they got on the airplane. Many people were wearing masks. They developed fevers while they were on the flight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Scary.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Everyone gets nervous at this point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You don't sound like you believe what the authorities are saying?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: I -- to be honest, I don't know yet. I don't have enough information. I would like to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Vanilla Ice was on the flight.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: They did say that -- that was the best part.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We hope Vanilla Ice and everybody else on the flight are OK. I have two questions; it's a two-parter. What is the best cure for a hangover? And what are your feelings about Juuls?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Oh, the vaping Juuls?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The vaping, yes.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: I get, like, I love jewels. Best cure for a hangover? I don't know. Drink less.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No! That's not what I was looking for.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Good answer. Good answer.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: I mean, I'm going to give you the same thing everyone does. Lots of water. Take it easy. Maybe a Tylenol. And some people say, you know, you have a drink in the morning. I'm not going to say that I do that.

utterances.utterance: You have a good bedside manner.

utterances.utterance: Vaping, very concerned about vaping. I have three kids myself. One of them just going off to college. And I know it's rampant out there. It's similar to cigarettes. We don't have the data on it. We don't know long-term consequences.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Without the tar. Without the tar.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I've not seen it. I'm questioning -- it doesn't have the tar in it. It's obviously better than smoking. Obviously.

utterances.utterance: OK, yes, it's kind of a maybe a two-parter. OK, when I'm in a car and the car's going downhill, I always get this weird feeling in my stomach. In my stomach. It's almost like -- do you ever stick your finger in your bellybutton and you get that weird feeling? What is that weird feeling? What is that? Is that what you call squeamishness or is it, like, some nervous system?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The jollies.

utterances.utterance: Is it a ghost?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: OK, well, that's not actually covered in medical school. But I'm going to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But you know what I'm talking about?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: So of course it is. It's a mix: it's mental and physical. So physically what's happening, when you roller coaster, when you go down that, you're actually -- gravity. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: So the gas and the contents in your intestines and your stomach move.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.utterance: So you're feeling it. Also, your brain has fear, anxiety, and that has direct impulses.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: No fear, Jesse. And it gets them to move a little bit more. So you're feeling a lot of different things. The bellybutton thing? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.utterance: My -- I have 2 questions. One is, because you do breast cancer diagnoses and treatment, there is confusion out there about whether women should get mammograms yearly. What's your opinion?

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: You know, we should talk about this for an entire hour, because that would save a lot of lives. A lot of confusion around that, and the main thing is, I recommend for average risk women, you know, there's 1 in 8 women will get breast cancer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: SAPHIER
utterances.utterance: Everyone knows a woman who's gotten it. For average risk women, a mammogram every year starting at age 40 until you don't think that you're necessarily going to live for 5 to 10 years after that. Confusion, because people like to talk about mortality. And although -- although sometimes you may diagnose breast cancer early, you treat it. That gives you 10 to 20 years. But you still may die from your breast cancer. So when you're looking at numbers, they say, "Well, they're still dying." Well, let me tell you, when I tell a 38-year-old woman that she has breast cancer and she has two toddlers at home, those 10 to 20 years are a big deal to her. So get your mammograms. Get them every year.
